title: 111_s1061
content: The Act titled "Uranium Enrichment Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund Reauthorization Act of 2009" reauthorizes the Uranium Enrichment Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to increase the fund amount to $790,000,000 and make adjustments related to inflation and timeline for the Uranium Enrichment Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to adjust the timeline for the Uranium Enrichment Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund, extending it to 12 years after the date of enactment of the Uranium Enrichment Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund Reauthorization Act of 2009. Additionally, the fund amount is increased to $790,000,000 with adjustments for inflation. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to extend the timeline for the Uranium Enrichment Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund to 12 years after the enactment of the Uranium Enrichment Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund Reauthorization Act of 2009. The fund amount is increased to $790,000,000 with adjustments for inflation. Additionally, reporting requirements are updated to reflect the new timeline. SEC. 3. RE-ENRICHMENT PLAN. The Secretary of Energy must develop a plan within 180 days to re-enrich and sell uranium tailings. The plan includes seeking a contract for re-enrichment with the operator of the Department of Energy's uranium enrichment facility in Paducah, Kentucky. The Secretary of Energy must develop a plan within 180 days to re-enrich and sell uranium tailings at the Paducah facility in Kentucky. A contract for re-enrichment should involve 50 percent of materials in cylinders and start within 90 days of the plan's publication. The Secretary can suspend or cancel the contract if obligations are not met by the facility operator. The Secretary of Energy must develop a plan to re-enrich and sell uranium tailings at the Paducah facility in Kentucky. The Secretary shall sell the product of re-enrichment and 50 percent of materials in cylinders to qualified buyers. The Secretary of Energy, under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, is authorized to possess materials in cylinders and must give preference to qualified buyers committed to re-enrichment in the U.S. Additionally, the Secretary aims to contract with the operator of the DOE's uranium enrichment facility in Paducah, Kentucky for re-enrichment of unsold materials. If the Secretary of Energy does not enter into a contract within 270 days, they may defer negotiation or sell materials in cylinders for re-enrichment.
